Introduction

Phimosis is a urologic condition characterized by the inability to retract the penile prepuce (foreskin) (

figure 1
).  It is a normal finding in infants and young children that is caused by congenital adhesions between the prepuce and glans (physiologic phimosis); it is typically a benign, self-limited condition that resolves by adolescence.  However, phimosis is considered pathologic when chronic inflammation leads to scarring and fibrosis of the preputial opening.  Pathologic phimosis causes symptoms (eg, painful erection, chronic urinary tract infections) and often requires surgical repair.

Pathophysiology

Physiologic phimosis



Physiologic phimosis is caused by congenital adhesions between the inner layer of the prepuce and the glans penis.  It is a normal clinical finding at birth and throughout early childhood.  Over time, penis enlargement, physiologic erections, and gentle manual retraction loosen these adhesions and allow greater mobility of the prepuce.  The time to achieve complete retraction varies, but most physiologic phimosis resolves by puberty.

Pathologic phimosis



Pathologic phimosis is the inability to retract the foreskin due to scarring, fibrosis, and stenosis of the preputial orifice.  The condition typically occurs in older children or adults who have chronic inflammation of the prepuce.  Risk factors for developing pathologic phimosis include the following:



  • Poor preputial hygiene:  increases the risk for infection and inflammation
  • Recurrent balanitis/balanoposthitis:  inflammation of the glans (balanitis) or the glans and prepuce (balanoposthitis), most often infectious (eg, Candida)
  • Trauma:  repeated or forcible manual retraction that creates microtears in the preputial orifice and leads to scarring
  • Balanitis xerotica obliterans:  chronic inflammatory dermatitis involving the prepuce
  • Diabetes mellitus:  increases the risk for infections

Clinical presentation

Physiologic phimosis



Clinical characteristics of physiologic phimosis include the following:



  • Typically asymptomatic
  • Ballooning of the foreskin with urination (benign, resolves with time)

Pathologic phimosis



Clinical characteristics of pathologic phimosis include the following:



  • Irritation, erythema, bleeding at preputial opening
  • Dysuria with recurrent urinary tract infections
  • Urinary retention, nocturnal enuresis (due to obstructed flow)
  • Repeat episodes of balanoposthitis
  • Painful erections and discomfort with intercourse
  • Stenosis of preputial orifice (the opening is surrounded by a white, fibrotic tissue)

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of phimosis is confirmed by an inability to retract the prepuce on examination.  Clinical history (eg, age of onset, symptomatology) helps determine physiologic or pathologic phimosis, which is important to guide management.



Differential diagnosis includes the following conditions:



  • Balanitis xerotica obliterans:  is a chronic inflammatory condition of the prepuce that causes scarring and sclerosis.  It can lead to phimosis over time.
  • Balanoposthitis (

    ):  is acute inflammation of the glans and prepuce that causes pain, swelling and difficulty with prepuce manipulation.  It is typically infectious in nature and associated with purulent discharge.
  • Paraphimosis:  refers to entrapment of the retracted foreskin behind the glans,which presents with an edematous glans and a tight band of foreskin constricting the distal penis.  The condition can occur with forced manipulation of a tight foreskin.

Laboratory evaluation and imaging



Laboratory testing is not necessary to diagnose phimosis; however, the following tests may identify predisposing conditions or associated complications:



  • Urinalysis to check for signs of urinary tract infection
  • Swabs and cultures when discharge or signs of infection (eg, balanoposthitis) are present (eg, assess for candida, group A Streptococcus)
  • Fingerstick glucose and hemoglobin A1c if diabetes mellitus is suspected


Imaging is not required in the evaluation of phimosis.

Management

Physiologic phimosis



Physiologic phimosis is typically a self-limited process that resolves over time.  However, if patients or parents are concerned that complete prepuce retraction has not been achieved by a specific age or if the patient has had recurrent infections, the following are appropriate interventions:



  • Topical corticosteroids (eg, betamethasone) promote skin elasticity to speed retraction.
  • Gentle manual retraction exercises should be performed several times per day.  Patients must be advised that forcible retraction should be avoided (may lead to pathologic phimosis).

Pathologic phimosis



Pathologic phimosis often requires surgical intervention.  Once the preputial opening has become fibrotic, steroids and stretching are often ineffective.  Surgical options include:



  • Preputioplasty:  surgical widening of the scarred preputial ring
  • Circumcision:  removal of the foreskin in recurrent or severe cases


Proper hygiene of the uncircumcised penis is essential to prevent infection and inflammation, which increase the risk for phimosis.  Patients should be educated about the importance of routine cleaning of the prepuce and the area underneath (once retraction is achieved).

Prognosis



Physiologic phimosis has an excellent prognosis.  Most cases spontaneously resolve without the need for intervention, and 95% of patients can retract the prepuce by adolescence.  Pathologic phimosis also has a good prognosis with appropriate treatment, although infection or trauma can cause recurrence.

Summary



Phimosis is the inability to retract the prepuce.  Physiologic phimosis is a normal finding in young children and often resolves spontaneously by adolescence.  Pathologic phimosis occurs when the preputial opening becomes scarred and fibrotic from chronic inflammation, infection, or trauma.  It typically requires surgical repair to prevent complications such as chronic urinary tract infection or urinary retention.
